Tom Sawyer.Action: Excitedly prepares to run away with friends for adventure.
Sneaks out of bed past his cousin silently.
Mocks and ties up his cousin Sid to the bed with ropes and a dirty sock to stop him from tattling.
Places a jar with a black spider on Sid’s chest to scare him.
Teases Sid with the dangerous spider in the jar, causing Sid to be scared stiff.
Greets Muff Potter warmly and talks with him in a friendly manner.
Encourages Joe and Ben to keep moving without showing concern for Muff's cautionary tale.
Identifies the spider as a black widow and correctly warns Sid about its danger.
Decides to test whether the spider is poisonous by escaping out the window rather than taking a safer approach.
Leads Joe and Ben on an adventurous night run, showing leadership and confidence.
Engages in running away from home, a reckless act indicating poor judgment in some respects.
Encourages friends with teasing but supports their decision to stay together on the journey.
Mocks the idea of families to justify running away, showing dismissiveness.
Leads friends in preparing a raft quickly and skillfully, setting sail confidently at night.
Encourages and motivates his friends to stay committed to their plan despite doubts.
Displays practical understanding of consequences by warning about no turning back after reaching the river junction.
Keeps spirits high and motivates boys by announcing progress and destination excitedly ('We made the Muddy, boys! Next stop -- New Orleans! Nothin’ can stop us now!')
Does not display direct interaction with others during the incident; is unconscious and vulnerable, reliant on a mysterious stranger's aid
Expresses confident enthusiasm about the journey, sets goals like reaching New Orleans, and attempts to steer the raft to avoid danger.
Fails to avoid collision with the sandbar, resulting in the raft capsizing and himself being injured and unconscious.
Greets family cheerfully at breakfast, tries to appear innocent.
Engages in imaginative play, sword-fighting an invisible opponent.
Feigns innocence and contrition to soften Aunt Polly's intentions when she's about to punish him.
Tests the switch and jokes about his impending whipping, showing playful but respectful behavior toward Aunt Polly.
Negotiates to avoid punishment with humor and cooperation rather than rebellion or deceit.
Feigns innocence and contrition skillfully to avoid punishment, uses wit to handle a difficult situation with Aunt Polly.
Attempts to downplay the severity of the switch by testing it and making light of the situation.
Sneaks out until late and worries Aunt Polly, causing her distress.
Offers to take the whipping for Aunt Polly, showing concern and responsibility.
Greets Jeb warmly and tries to engage him before tricking him into painting the fence.
Deceives Jeb by faking an injury to manipulate him into painting the fence.
Takes initiative to start painting the fence instead of avoiding work.
Cleverly persuades Jeb to do the painting by tricking him with a fake injury.
Successfully avoids punishment by making Jeb do the work, displaying quick thinking and confidence.
Tricks Jeb with a fake injury causing him to react impulsively.
Pretends to enjoy whitewashing the fence, making it appear fun so Billy Newton wants to paint it for him, cleverly trading work for marbles.
Engages Joe and Ben with an imaginative plan about outlaws modeled on Robin Hood, showing friendliness and inclusiveness.
Uses sarcasm towards Joe and Ben initially but then quickly moves on to involve them in new play.
Plays a playful role of Robin Hood to entertain Thatcher and Becky.
Swallows his nervousness and tries to continue interaction even while embarrassed around Becky.
Threatens to take the Judge's valuables in a playful, non-harmful way.
Greets Huck warmly and shows genuine interest in his whereabouts.
Acknowledges Huck’s help in pulling him out last night, expressing gratitude.
Engages Huck in friendly conversation and willingly follows him to see his camp.
Dodges trees, leaps over logs, pursues Huck confidently through the forest.
Recognizes Huck quickly and engages him, showing social awareness and memory.
Admits to being whipped for stealing a pie but shifts blame to Sid, showing some evasiveness rather than straightforwardness.
Thanks Huck for saving his life and offers to visit him again.
Extends his hand to Huck, saying 'It's what friends do,' to reestablish friendship.
Assures Huck not to worry about Aunt Polly's disapproval and expresses gladness Huck returned.
Half-serious threat to punch Huck in the nose during friendly banter.
Expresses gratitude to Huck for saving his life and sincerely seeks to restore their friendship by extending a handshake.
Backs off from Huck's challenge partially out of fear and partially respect, showing social awareness and conflict avoidance.
Accuses others (like Sid) to avoid punishment and doesn't fully take responsibility for actions like stealing a pie or watermelons.
Laughs and jokes with Huck confidently, demonstrating social skill and ease of interaction.
Dismisses consequences from Aunt Polly about associating with Huck despite acknowledging risks.
Arrives late on purpose, shows defiance to authority but playfully accepts punishment.
Sits beside Becky Thatcher despite teasing, offers her an apple and smiles, engages in playful friendliness.
Arrives late on purpose, tries to avoid punishment by having no excuse, but accepts his punishment with mock horror and good humor, outsmarting himself in a clever way.
Trudges down to sit with the girls as punishment, but turns the situation into an opportunity to engage with Becky by offering an apple confidently.
Offers an apple to Becky as a friendly gesture despite her rejection.
Continues to play and interact with Becky by following her and engaging in a playful chase.
Follows Becky at a distance, tries to catch her in a playful game of hide and seek.
Panics briefly when he loses sight of Becky after turning a corner.
Collides with Injun Joe but does not provoke him; shows fear when threatened but remains polite when Muff Potter intervenes.
Does not retaliate or escalate conflict with Injun Joe; quickly runs away when encouraged.
Nonchalantly pretends to be a tightrope walker on the bridge, attempting to entertain or lighten the mood for Becky.
Uses a shortcut through the woods to catch up with Becky, showing knowledge of the area and quick thinking.
Is caught off guard by Injun Joe and physically threatened, showing momentary fear and vulnerability.
Balances himself to impress Becky and seems playful despite being shoved.
Laughs off an embarrassing fall and interacts humorously with Huck Finn.
Shows friendly curiosity about Huck's dead cat and listens to his superstitions.
Eagerly wants to accompany Huck on a spooky adventure despite possible danger.
Expresses fear and is comforted by Huck chanting a protective spell.
Thanks Huck after being freed from vines.
Shares his concerns and observations openly with Huck during the graveyard scene.
Whispers important, serious information to Huck about dangerous characters and grave-robbing plans.
Shows caution and concern about grave-robbing, indicating a sense of morality and awareness of wrongdoing.
Recognizes the danger posed by Injun Joe and discusses it cautiously with Huck.
Accurately identifies the grave robbers' activity and reacts with appropriate fear and caution.
Exhibits excitement and alertness upon discovering the significance of the box labeled 'MURRELL.'
Explains the background story of One-Eye Murrell and the pirate treasure confidently to others.
Merely observes the conflict over the box and treasure without intervening or taking decisive action.
Knows the danger and attempts to escape quickly with Huck despite the threat.
Jacket gets caught on a branch and rips, slowing escape momentarily.
Agrees to keep the secret of the murder to protect Huck and himself, showing loyalty and seriousness about their friendship.
Makes up a playful yet sincere oath to seal their friendship, demonstrating warmth and friendliness.
Accepts Huck's reasoning about danger and agrees to keep the secret, showing situational awareness and pragmatism.
Writes the oath and makes up a creative loyalty pledge, demonstrating initiative and leadership in a tense moment.
Fret about losing his cat's-eye, which is trivial given the gravity of the situation, showing a slight lack of prioritization.
Screams in fear when Injun Joe threatens him during the night.
Does not resist or complain when Aunt Polly and Sid forcibly pull out his tooth despite his fear and discomfort.
Wakes up abruptly and screams when threatened by Injun Joe, showing panic and lack of control under danger.
Tries to deny his toothache despite obvious pain and disorientation, showing avoidance rather than assertive problem-solving.
Endures having his painful tooth pulled while restrained, demonstrating some level of endurance but not active competence or control.
Yells at Mary to go away while he is naked, showing embarrassment but no malice.
Holds his mouth in pain but glares at Sid playfully, showing sibling rivalry but no cruelty.
Breaks into a devilish grin when Becky offers herself to be pushed into the creek, engaging in playful teasing.
Helps Becky down from the rail in a gentlemanly fashion.
Responds to Becky's apology and playfully educates her about being sweethearts, engaging kindly and sincerely.
Tom handles a tricky social situation with Becky confidently and playfully, showing social intelligence and charm.
Tom endures Sid's teasing about his lost tooth without losing composure, demonstrating resilience.
Tom is surprised by Becky’s presence but quickly recovers and engages her, showing quick thinking.
Tom cautiously navigates the apology and interaction with Becky, showing emotional awareness.
Tom does not back down from teasing or awkward social moments, maintaining confidence.
Promises Becky he won't tell anyone her secret.
Gives Becky a doorknob as an engagement ring.
Boasts about a previous engagement to Amy Lawrence immediately after giving Becky the doorknob.
Is hurt and confused when Becky reacts negatively but only responds with pride and marches off.
Grins and confidently initiates a romantic moment with Becky, showing boldness and social confidence.
Presents Becky with a doorknob as an engagement ring, trying to be charming but misjudging the situation.
Continues to engage despite Becky's upset reaction, indicating persistence though possibly lacking sensitivity.
Mopes and is confused about what he did wrong, showing lack of understanding of social cues.
Quickly picks up the doorknob and marches off, showing a sense of pride and self-confidence.
Fails to immediately grasp the seriousness of the news about the murder and the school being called off.
Pushes his way through the crowd to witness the events
Observes with disbelief and horror as the crowd unjustly accuses Muff Potter
Pushes his way through a bustling crowd to witness a critical event, showing initiative and engagement.
Unable to influence the crowd or clarify the situation despite understanding the injustice unfolding.
Does not intervene while the crowd threatens Muff Potter, remaining silent as injustice unfolds.
Listens and reacts with disbelief to crowd's outrage and accusations, but does not intervene or speak up here.
Locks eyes with poor Muff and feels his fear.
Is about to say something to Muff but does not.
Quickly searches for Huck when he notices him missing.
Locks eyes with Muff and feels his fear, seeks Huck for support and reassurance.
Almost speaks to Muff but refrains, then fails to immediately find Huck in the crowd.
Insists on helping Muff Potter even though it is dangerous and unpopular, showing loyalty and a sense of justice.
Challenges Huck when Huck refuses to help, appealing to their friendship and trying to inspire empathy.
Shakes his head in disappointment and walks away when Huck rejects his appeal, showing sincerity and emotional openness.
Uses a clever idea to avoid breaking the oath while still trying to do the right thing, demonstrating thoughtfulness and concern for moral integrity.
Hides a smile, proud of Huck when Huck decides to team up with him.
Shows alarm and concern when he sees his cat's-eye marble in Injun Joe's possession.
Carefully plans and executes sneaking into the tavern area by rolling a rain barrel, balancing on it, and peering through a window to spy on Injun Joe and Emmett.
Recognizes the significance of Injun Joe having his cat's-eye marble, showing attentive observation and connection of clues.
Loses balance and causes a loud crash, drawing attention to himself and Huck, which jeopardizes their spying mission.
Shows pride and confidence when Huck admits he needs Tom's help, indicating some leadership and self-assurance.
Leads and supports Huck in following Injun Joe quietly, sharing ideas about his movements.
Borrow Muff Potter's raft without explicit permission, implying some disregard for property or permission.
Carefully plans and executes a stealthy night operation to follow Injun Joe by borrowing Muff Potter's raft and manning the rudder confidently.
Whispers instructions and collaborates well with Huck in a tense situation, showing situational awareness and leadership.
Decides to leave the raft secured on the bank in case a quick getaway is needed.
Fails to notice the raft floating away after it comes loose.
Observes surroundings carefully in the woods and calls out when Huck is missing.
Engages in playful camaraderie with Huck, showing social intelligence.
Encourages Huck to join in stealing the map from Injun Joe.
Shows bravery and determination by attempting to sneak the map despite Huck's fear.
Uses camouflage and stealth to approach Injun Joe and attempt to steal the map while he is asleep, showing careful observation and bravery.
Freezes when a twig snaps and when a nearby cannon fires, losing the map in the process, showing nervousness and loss of control.
Tom laughs upon realizing others think he drowned, showing a playful and lighthearted nature.
Leaps back in fear and hides with Huck to avoid danger, demonstrating self-preservation rather than self-sacrifice.
Leaps back quickly reacting to cannon fire, instinctively avoids danger alongside Huck.
Looks around thoughtfully to assess the situation at Jackson's Island shore.
Immediately reacts to missing raft situation, showing awareness of his environment.
Laughs upon realizing others think he is drowned, demonstrating quick acceptance and humor in a tense situation.
Laughs and enjoys tricking others into thinking he drowned, takes pleasure in others' worry.
Notices and comments on Aunt Polly's sadness but focuses on his own amusement rather than her feelings.
Deceives others into believing he drowned, demonstrating cleverness and confidence in executing a complex trick.
Enjoys the success of his prank and shows awareness of others' reactions, indicating social intelligence and presence of mind.
Follows Huck promptly in paddling toward Injun Joe's location, showing initiative and readiness to act.
Smiles and laughs despite the dangerous situation, suggesting some emotional control and confidence.
Does not express concern or hesitation about Injun Joe escaping, possibly indicating a lack of full reckoning with danger or responsibility.
Faces a threatening situation with Huck, showing willingness to confront fear together by entering the haunted house for shelter.
Questions Huck’s confidence about ghosts, displaying skepticism but also shared courage.
Responds quickly to the threat by urging Huck to run when they hear the rattling and clanking noises approaching.
Leads the decision to seek shelter in the haunted house despite the scary reputation and ongoing rainstorm.
Tries to be brave and rational about the haunted house, discussing ghost presence with Huck.
Experiences fear when the door slams off its hinges, showing a natural human reaction rather than calm control.
Jumps up impulsively to confront a threat without thinking, but is restrained by Huck.
Shares an excited grin with Huck, indicating camaraderie and trust.
Successfully evades Injun Joe to avoid capture and attempts to secure the treasure.
Fails to save the treasure map from burning, losing crucial evidence.
Shows concern over losing the map and treasure, and for Muff; expresses worry about Injun Joe and respects Huck's caution.
Listens attentively and shows empathy when Huck reveals his painful family background and emotional hardships.
Responds to loss of the map and treasure with sober acceptance and considers the danger of Injun Joe, showing awareness and caution.
Wishes he understood the meaning of 'Number Two, under the cross,' showing curiosity and problem-solving mindset.
Engages earnestly in conversation to learn about Huck’s difficult past and Injun Joe’s danger, demonstrating social intelligence and emotional perception.
Does not attempt to pursue Injun Joe’s wagon when it departs at high speed, recognizing the futility and danger.
Shows mischievous delight in his own fake funeral, invites Huck to attend
Reacts with glee to seeing Aunt Polly, Sid, and Mary looking distraught at his funeral
Observes other kids talking about being beaten up by him
Notices Becky looking sweet and sad, paying attention to her feelings
Observes and understands the meaning of funeral bells, showing awareness and reasoning.
Pretends to be dead and plans to attend his own funeral, demonstrating cleverness and strategic thinking.
Runs down the hill eagerly to participate in his own funeral prank, showing confidence and boldness.
Tom's name is mentioned as the last true owner of the marble, indicating his involvement and standing among peers.
Everyone mourns Tom as if he were significant, showing he commanded respect and presence even in absence.
Feigns injury by falling through the ceiling to garner attention and enjoy the adulation of the crowd.
Shows a twinge of regret for Aunt Polly's sadness but quickly dismisses it with a flippant comment under his breath.
Responds confidently and with bravado when Becky approaches, greeting her with a casual 'Hello, Becky. Ain't you glad to see me?'
Does not evade or escalate the situation when punched by Becky, instead holds his bloody nose, accepting the consequence calmly.
Tries to persuade Huck to stay, reminded Huck of their friendship.
Not giving up on Huck despite harsh rejection.
Does not respond negatively or mock Huck's lifestyle or harsh words.
Tries to persuade Huck to stay, attempts to find reasons and argue emotionally.
Fails to understand Huck's motives and the dangers involved, shows confusion and emotional reasoning rather than practical strategy.
Admits to losing the cat's-eye marble and confesses the truth to Injun Joe when confronted.
Fears for his life but obeys Injun Joe's command to fetch and hand over the knife without resistance.
Tries to deny owning the cat's-eye marble despite being caught, then quickly admits the truth and explains his situation.
Though terrified and paralyzed when threatened with a knife, he cautiously obeys the instruction to fetch and hand over the knife, avoiding immediate violence.
Is initially frightened and frozen, showing hesitation and fear in a dangerous confrontation.
Can't bring himself to kill Injun Joe despite danger, showing fear but also restraint.
Hopes for affection from Becky but is met with rejection, responds by sitting dejectedly rather than lashing out.
Responds politely and sincerely to Widow Douglas' concern, admitting his feelings honestly.
Cannot bring himself to kill Injun Joe despite the danger, showing hesitation and fear.
Takes note of town gossip about the trial and hanging, indicating awareness of his surroundings.
Shows emotional vulnerability and mopes about his troubles, seeming dejected after Becky rejects him.
Responds politely and respectfully to Widow Douglas’s advice, showing some emotional maturity.
Brings Muff Potter cornbread in jail and shows concern for his well-being.
Expresses belief in Muff's innocence despite others doubting him.
Acknowledges Muff's flaws honestly but still defends his fundamental goodness.
Struggles to comfort Muff and offers hope, though unsure himself.
Brings cornbread to Muff Potter in jail, tries to comfort him, listens to his fears and expresses belief in his innocence despite others doubting.
Feels distressed and struggles to find words to reassure Muff; exhibits emotional discomfort and uncertainty.
Expresses inner conflict about breaking an oath to protect someone who might be harmed otherwise.
Relies on Aunt Polly's understanding and advice, showing trust and openness.
Uses dark humor when discussing the consequences of breaking an oath, which may distance him emotionally.
Considers the moral dilemma of breaking an oath to prevent harm to an innocent person, showing thoughtfulness and awareness of consequences.
Appears emotionally conflicted and anxious about the situation, indicating some internal struggle in managing his feelings and the complexity of the problem.
Sneaks into the back of the courtroom and looks around during Muff Potter's trial, eyes narrow mad as hell when Injun Joe falsely accuses Muff.
Sneaks into the back of the courtroom and observes attentively with a focused, angry look as Injun Joe testifies falsely against Muff Potter.
Takes the stand in court to testify despite fear and threat from Injun Joe, swears to tell the truth.
Mumbles and hesitates in court when questioned, shows nervousness.
Responds angrily to Dobbins' mocking comment, showing frustration but also stands firm.
Faces danger silently, keeping eye contact on Injun Joe's threatening behavior to protect himself and reveal truth.
Swears to tell the truth under pressure, despite fear and intimidation from Injun Joe.
Attempts to answer questions in court but stumbles and mumbles, indicating nervousness and some difficulty in articulating clearly.
Uses a humorous excuse ('trying to get rid of warts') to deflect a serious question, showing quick thinking and presence of mind.
Gives a hesitant and unclear answer ('Ie. Tee.') under direct threat, which could indicate lack of confidence or failure to produce a clear testimony.
Stands up in court to truthfully reveal events despite personal danger.
Protects Muff Potter by implicating Injun Joe, showing loyalty and sincerity.
Accurately recalls and insists on correct details in court, confidently defends the truth about the stabbing with clear recollection and quick thinking.
Courageously confronts Injun Joe, using the Bible as a shield from a thrown knife, demonstrating quick reflexes and bravery under pressure.
Effectively exposes the real culprit and changes the course of the trial, showing skill in persuasion and justice.
Testifies to save Muff Potter, telling the truth despite personal risk.
Appears terrified and withdrawn at home, showing vulnerability but not interacting warmly.
Silent and sullen when asked about the Harvest Celebration, showing withdrawal from social warmth momentarily.
Testifies in court and his testimony frees Muff Potter.
Sits reading about knights but is visibly anxious and unable to concentrate due to fear.
Shuts down Sid's comment with 'Shut up, Sid.'
Becomes furious and throws a pillow at Sid's head
Lies awake, scared but cautious in the dark, showing vulnerability
Furious reaction to Sid's teasing by hurling a pillow shows emotional impulsiveness rather than calm competence.
Lies awake alertly, notices suspicious sounds and movements, showing awareness and a cautious attitude.
Freezes and hides under the covers rather than investigating or confronting the danger directly.
Tentatively peeks out from under covers to observe the situation, indicating cautious curiosity rather than confident action.
Chooses to help Muff despite the oath he swore to Huck, believing it wrong not to help someone in need.
Attempts to reason with Huck about breaking their oath for a greater moral good.
Left alone by Huck who escapes without further explanation or support.
Tom hesitates and shows concern about the oath, but chooses to help Muff because it is the right thing to do, despite the risk to himself.
Tom is caught off guard and is left alone after Huck escapes quickly; he does not prevent Huck from abandoning him.
Approaches Becky with a shy smile, initiates friendly interaction.
Runs after Becky when she flees embarrassed, trying to understand what is wrong.
Expresses shock and bewilderment at Becky's sudden announcement of marriage, showing openness and sincerity.
Emerges shyly from the cornfield and approaches Becky with a shy smile, initiates interaction confidently despite social awkwardness.
Chases after Becky when she runs away, showing initiative and persistence.
Appears bewildered and shocked by Becky's declaration of marriage, indicating occasional social naivety or lack of awareness.
Responds with an ironic and humorous comment about his situation (married and divorced at the same time), showing some quick wit.
Mocks Becky in a teasing tone, telling her to be careful.
Dares Becky to go down the dark tunnel, provoking her pride.
Follows Becky into the dark, foreboding tunnel despite apparent danger and adults calling to the children.
Smirks at Becky's boldness and shows some admiration.
Dares Becky to enter a dangerous tunnel, then follows her despite potential danger and the adults' calls, showing confidence and boldness.
Mocks Becky initially, possibly provoking risky behavior without considering consequences.
Pretends to be aloof and unimpressed about the cave, but smiles at Becky, trying to impress her by cupping his hands and echoing his voice.
Pretends to be aloof and unimpressed, using knowledge of the cave to impress Becky by naming caverns and calling one 'Aladdin's Palace'.
Cups hands over his mouth and echoes his voice loudly in the cavern to impress Becky, showing confidence and social skill.
Fails to realize the danger of staying behind in the cave or getting lost as indicated by Aunt Polly and Judge Thatcher's concern.
Grabs Becky and pulls her out of the way of the falling boulders during the cave avalanche.
Tries to stop Becky from yelling and risking danger in the cave.
Grabs Becky and pulls her out of the way of falling boulders after a cave-in is triggered.
Initially yells into the cavern despite danger, disregarding safety.
Reassures Becky when they are trapped, says 'Don't you worry, Becky. We'll find a way out.'
Takes the lantern from Becky when the candle goes out to provide light for both of them.
Guides candle light to illuminate the skeleton to comfort or inform Becky after her scream.
Expresses delight upon seeing the skeleton (One-Eye Murrell) in a dangerous situation.
Calmly reassures Becky despite being trapped, takes initiative to find a way out by following the flickering candle and discovering a tunnel.
Keeps calm after the candle goes out and promptly takes the lantern from Becky, showing resourcefulness and care.
Guides Becky through a dark cave, illuminating and identifying a skeleton confidently with excitement rather than fear.
Does not panic despite the dangerous and unknown surroundings, shows leadership and confidence.
Mentions the presence of water in the cave with a positive spin, trying to maintain morale.
Relies on the lantern as the only source of light but does not express despair or helplessness when the candle is almost out.
Grabs Becky quickly and runs to protect her from danger.
Calmly reassures Becky despite frightening circumstances.
Recognizes the danger quickly upon seeing Injun Joe and immediately decides to run with Becky into another tunnel.
Chooses a direction at the tunnel junction confidently to continue escape, showing quick decision-making under pressure.
Comforts Becky and protects her when bats attack, demonstrating presence of mind and protective instincts.
Notes and interprets clues inside the cave (Roman numeral II and rock formation), showing observational skills and intelligence.
Encourages Becky to escape and find help despite danger to himself.
Fights Injun Joe to protect himself and others.
Notices the Roman Numeral and cross-shaped rock formation, deduces their significance to find the way out and location of treasure.
Encourages Becky to escape and bring help while he digs for treasure, showing presence of mind and prioritization.
Uses a rusty cutlass to dig frantically to find the treasure chest.
Fights Injun Joe by swiping his cutlass into Joe's leg and charging, showing courage but engaging in a risky physical fight.
Loses grip on cutlass and is overpowered by Injun Joe temporarily, indicating a setback in the fight.
Shouts to warn Huck and distracts Injun Joe, risking himself to save Huck's life.
Shouts at Injun Joe and distracts him at a critical moment by threatening to throw the treasure chest, showing quick thinking and courage under pressure.
Grins at Huck despite being in pain, indicating confidence and morale-boosting leadership.
Helps Huck up after Injun Joe falls.
Brings Huck back into the light when townspeople appear, showing pride and recognition of Huck.
Winks at Huck after revealing their treasure, causing Huck to smile for the first time.
Tricks Injun Joe into leaping over the cliff to his doom.
Receives warm embraces from Aunt Polly and Becky; greeted with cheers by the crowd, revealing his positive connection and affection from community and loved ones.
Shows affection and friendliness by smiling and waving to Becky and promising to attend her birthday party.
Enjoys the attention of his young admirers and accepts the role of a celebrity, indicating he appreciates social warmth and connection.
Speaks somewhat boastfully about the burdens of being a hero, complaining about social obligations and public attention.
Turns gloomy and shows a hint of reluctance or dissatisfaction beneath the surface conviviality, suggesting some insincerity or conflicted feelings about his social role.
Successfully discovers treasure with Huck, gaining public recognition and admiration.
Wears new clothes and enjoys being a reluctant celebrity, showing social awareness.
Manages multiple social obligations and admirers, demonstrating confidence in social navigation.
Expresses reluctance and gloom about fame and social expectations, indicating some internal conflict but not incompetence.
Takes off his fancy clothes and gives them to other kids, expressing a preference for freedom over money and fame.
Shouts happily while running toward Huck's camp, excited to see his friend.
Expresses indignant surprise at a boy poking through Huck's possessions, showing protectiveness.
Questions Huck's decision to give up his camp and move to town, showing concern and disbelief rather than support.
Expresses disbelief and disapproval of Huck's desire to attend church social and 'get civilized,' showing resistance to change but concern for Huck.
Goes ballistic and declares he won't stop Huck but will stay and live free, demonstrating loyalty and respect for Huck's choices.
Turns to audience confident Huck will return, indicating trust and hopefulness in his friend.
Shows seething righteous indignation and stewing while watching Huck leave, prioritizing his own ideals over friendly acceptance of Huck's change.
Insists on going with Huck to look out for him, showing concern and a sense of responsibility.
Boasts about knowing the tricks and how Huck will be lost without him.
Confidently claims to know tricks that nobody else does; offers to look out for Huck in a potentially dangerous situation.
Expresses reluctance but goes after Huck, indicating some hesitation about the risk.
